questions.text: A 34-year-old woman is admitted to the hospital after a car collision. Physical examination reveals a mallet finger. Which of the following conditions is expected to be present during radiographic examination?

options.label: A
options.text: Fracture of the fourth or fifth metacarpal bone

options.label: B
options.text: A separation of the extension expansion over the middle interphalangeal joint

options.label: C
options.text: Compression of the deep ulnar nerve by dislocation of the lunate bone

options.label: D
options.text: Avulsion fracture of the dorsum of the distal phalanx

questions.correct_answer: D. Avulsion fracture of the dorsum of the distal phalanx

questions.text: A 56-year-old woman is admitted to the hospital after a severe car crash. A large portion of her chest wall needed to be surgically removed and replaced with a Musculo-osseous scapular graft involving the medial border of the scapula. Which of the following arteries will most likely recompensate the blood supply to the entire scapula?

A 48-year-old woman who has had a stroke complains of weakness of her right arm and weakness of her right lower face. Language assessment reveals the following speech deficits: slow, labored speech; dysarthric, telegraphic speech; usually good comprehension; and poor repetition. Which of the following types of aphasia do these neurologic findings describe best?

A male pt. who is married with a child from his wife's previous marriage, presents with inability to have a child in common. He has h/o chronic lower respiratory infections. What does the physician suspect?
A 22-year-old patient has dryness of the corneal surface of his eye because of a lack of tears. Which of the following nerves may be damaged?

options.label: A
options.text: Proximal portion of the lacrimal nerve

options.label: B
options.text: Zygomatic branch of the facial nerve

questions.text: The drummer presents with hearing loss. Otoscopic examination reveals loss of contraction of the tensor tympani and the stapedius, which prevents damage to the eardrum and middle ear ossicles. These muscles are most likely controlled by which of the following nerves?

A 54-year-old patient with complaints of recent dizziness and progressive, bilateral sensorineural hearing loss with onset in adolescent age.She complains of increasing hearing loss for over 15 years. Her audiogram is shown as follows, She also undergoes computed tomography (CT) scanning of the temporal bones. The scans are shown as follows.Choose the most appropriate statement regarding the diagnosis :

options.label: A
options.text: Cochlear implants is the first choice for Hearing rehabilitation

options.label: B
options.text: Stapedotomy will be the part of treatment protocol.

options.label: C
options.text: Osteogenesis imperfecta can lead to a similar CT appearance but is far more common in the temporal bone

options.label: D
options.text: Bisphosphonates will be of no use in stabilising hearing in cochlear cases.

questions.correct_answer: B. Stapedotomy will be the part of treatment protocol.

questions.text: A female presented with long standing nasal obstruction. She also complaints about comments from her friends telling about foul smell coming from her nose which she could not recognise. On evaluation, atrophic rhinitis is diagnosed. What can be the etiology in this patient to develop secondary atrophic rhinitis?
Which of the following part of cochlear implant is implanted in scala tympani during surgery:

A case of carcinoma larynx with the involvement of Left vocal cord, left aryepiglottic fold, left ventricular band and invading into paraglottic space. Which of the following statements is true for the managements of this case?
A 5 year old boy while having dinner suddenly becomes aphonic and is brought to the casualty for the complaint of respiratory difficult. What should be the appropriate management?

A patient presented with a 3.5-cm size lymph node enlargement, which was hard and present in the submandibular region. Examination of the head and neck did not yield any lesion. Which of the following Investigations should follow?
All of the following conditions are associated with snoring except:

A 12-year-old previously healthy child presented to the emergency department with fever, throat pain, and difficulty breathing. The previous history was unremarkable, except for perforated appendicitis 15 months prior. One week prior to admission, the patient reported the symptom of a sore throat that improved slightly after 2 days of self-prescribed penicillin. However, a worsening sore throat returned the day prior to admission. In the ED, the patient was found to have a right-sided sore throat, pain while swallowing, odynophagia, poor oral (p.o.) intake, right neck tenderness, and a fever of 40.1°C. The patient also reported a recent development of trismus and muffled “hot potato” voice. X-Ray demonstrate soft tissue swelling posterior to the pharynx, with a widening of the prevertebral soft tissue. All of the following are true about diagnosis except

options.label: A
options.text: Examination of pharynx shows a midline bulge on posterior pharyngeal wall

options.label: B
options.text: Mostly presents as a pediatric airway emergency

options.label: C
options.text: Results of suppuration of lymph nodes.

options.label: D
options.text: It extends from skull base to bifurcation of trachea

questions.correct_answer: A. Examination of pharynx shows a midline bulge on posterior pharyngeal wall

questions.text: Paroxysmal sneezing on getting up early in morning from bed is associated with ?
Symptoms and signs of foreign bodies at different levels depend on the area of involvement. Palpatory thud, audible snap is seen in

A 22-year-old female college student comes to the hospital OPD complaining of palpitations. The patient has had occasional incidences of rapid heart rates but never lasting for more than 2 minutes. In this instance, the heart rate has been elevated for 15 minutes. The patient has only been sleeping 4 hours a night while studying for examinations and is consuming “more than the usual amount” of coffee to help her remain alert. ECG shows ventricular tachycardia, characterized by narrow QRS complexes at a rate of 180/min. Atrial P waves are also present at a rate of 180/min, but the QRS complexes precede the P wave. Carotid sinus massage causes pulse rate to abruptly decrease to 80 beats/min. This effect is due to activation of which of the following?

options.label: A
options.text: Parasympathetic nerves supplying the sinoatrial node

options.label: B
options.text: Parasympathetic nerves supplying the atrioventricular node

options.label: C
options.text: Sympathetic nerves supplying the sinoatrial node

options.label: D
options.text: Sympathetic nerves supplying the atrioventricular node

questions.correct_answer: B. Parasympathetic nerves supplying the atrioventricular node

questions.text: A 55-year-old man comes to the clinic complaining of fatigue and persistent shortness of breath, which becomes worse during exercise. He has a history of respiratory infections and has a chronic cough that is worse in the morning. The patient has smoked cigarettes since he was a teenager; currently he estimates smoking one pack of cigarettes a day. He is in mild respiratory distress, with an elevated respiratory rate and shallow breaths. An end-expiratory wheeze is heard on auscultation. This patient’s chest radiograph is normal and arterial blood gases are PO2 75 mm Hg, PCO2 42 mm Hg, and pH 7.32. In this patient, ventilation is being stimulated by afferent inputs from which of the following structures?

options.label: D
options.text: Aortic arch and carotid body chemoreceptors but not central chemoreceptors

questions.correct_answer: D. Aortic arch and carotid body chemoreceptors but not central chemoreceptors

questions.text: A 22-year-old man enters the hospital emergency department after severing a major artery in a motorcycle accident. It is estimated that he has lost approximately 700mL of blood. His blood pressure id 90/50 mm Hg. Which set of changes would be expected in response to hemorrhage in this man?

options.label: A
options.text: Increased sympathetic activity, increased heart rate, increased peripheral resistance

options.label: B
options.text: Increased sympathetic activity, decreased heart rate, decreased peripheral resistance

options.label: C
options.text: Increased sympathetic activity, increased heart rate, decreased peripheral resistance

options.label: D
options.text: Increased sympathetic activity, decreased heart rate, increased peripheral resistance

questions.correct_answer: A. Increased sympathetic activity, increased heart rate, increased peripheral resistance

questions.text: A new seizure drug is being investigated that binds to and activates GABA-A receptors in the CNS. During their experiments, a researcher uses a micro electrode to measure the RMP of a neuron. He records RMP of -70mV. Which of the following membrane potentials is likely to be recorded following exposure to the drug?

A 75-year-old man gives a history of having worked in factory where asbestos was used as an insulator. He worked in this factory for a period of five years in his early 40s. He now has severe shortness of breath. His chest physician diagnoses him as a case of asbestosis. Which of the following flow-volume loops will be typically seen in this patient?

A clinical experiment is conducted in which one group is given 50gms of glucose i/v and another group is given 50gms of glucose orally. Which of the following can explain why the oral glucose load is cleared from the blood at a faster rate compared with the i/v glucose load?

A Sindhi couple is seeking genetic counselling for an inherited anemia, although both of them do not have any anemia, but the blood investigations show microcytic hypochromic picture. HPLC finding of husband is HbA 92%, HbA2 7%, HbF1% and wife HbA-94.5%, HbA2 4.5% HbF 1%. What is the likely hood of them having a child born with inherited anemia?

33-year-old woman has experienced low grade fevers, night sweats, and generalized malaise for the past 2 months. On physical examination she has non-tender cervical and supraclavicular lymphadenopathy. A cervical lymph node biopsy is performed. On microscopic examination at high magnification there are occasional CD15+ and CD30+ Reed-Sternberg cells along with large and small lymphocytes and bands of fibrosis. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 32-year female presents with tinnitus. Further examination revealed a mass in the cerebellopontine angle. Family history suggests her father also had similar tumor which was resected surgically and is doing well after that. Histological examination from the tumor is as follows what is the likely diagnosis and most likely mutation leading to such familial tumor?

A 52-year-old man has had increasing fatigue for the past 6 months. On physical examination he has a palpable spleen tip. Laboratory studies show a WBC count of 189,000/microliter. The peripheral blood smear shows many mature and immature myeloid cells present. Cytogenetic analysis of cells obtained via bone marrow aspiration reveals a t(9:22) translocation. Which of the following cellular mechanism would lead to neoplasm in this patient?

options.label: C
options.text: Inability to arrest the cell cycle at G1S

questions.correct_answer: B. An increased tyrosine kinase activity

questions.text: A 10-year child presents with rhinitis and fever. Examination showed temperature of 101 F, the nasal mucosa is red and there is an increased secretion. He was prescribed with Aspirin by the local physician. After consuming aspirin the child develops breathless ness, however the temperature is 98 F. Which of the following could have lead above mentioned side effects?

options.label: A
options.text: An increased IgE secretion after drug administration

questions.text: An 8-month-old infant is admitted to pediatric ward due to bacterial pneumonia for the fifth time. He also had a bout of otitis media. The infant is irritable, has poor feeding and had an episode of seizures few days back. The child’s jaw muscle undergo spastic contraction when jaw was tapped. Serum immunoglobulins were normal. What is the likely diagnosis?

An 8 year child presents with abdominal pain. The pain is located to the right hypochondrium. The pain is colicky and disappears after few minutes. An ultrasound shows gall stones, and a shrunken spleen. Rest of physical examination is normal. A peripheral blood examination showed abnormal shaped RBC and you start suspecting a genetic disease. Which of the following is true about this child?

A 2-days old infant has extensive crying and not passed meconium. A radiological imaging was done with barium which is as shown in the image. A biopsy was taken from narrowed segment, and the dilated segment proximal to the narrow segment. Which of the following is likely finding on the biopsy?
A 35 year old is diagnosed to have an inherited disease due to mutation of HFE gene. Which of the following is not the likely manifestation of this disease?

A 32 year old male presents with reduced urine output for last 24 hours. He has not history of pharyngitis or pyoderma in the past month, he has no history of any major surgical procedures except he underwent extraction of third molar 1 month back. BP is 140/90, pulse is 90/min. Auscultation of heart shows a murmur in the mitral area. Urine examination shows 10 RBC/HPF and a few RBC casts. Which of the following mechanism would have led to such a manifestation in this patient?

options.label: B
options.text: Reduced ANP due to cardiac lesion

options.label: C
options.text: Excessive ANP due to cardiac lesions

questions.text: A patient presents with bleeding per rectum and colonoscopy shows a polypoid growth of 2 cm in diameter. An excision biopsy was done and histology is as shown in the image. What is the likely diagnosis?

A 6 year child has a sore throat runny nose low grade fever and malaise. He was prescribed with antihistaminic and NSAIDs and sent home. He continues to take the drugs for a week time and feeling better. On day eight he has swelling in his both wrists and is unable to move. Clinically the wrists are tender for which the physician increased the NSAID dose and sent home again. Three days later presents with vomiting of blood and pain in the abdomen. CBC shows Hb 13g/dL, TLC 10000/cu.mm, platelet count 190000/cu.mm. Physical examination is as shown in the image. What is the likely diagnosis?

A 65 year old retired industrial worker presents with increasing dyspnoea, cough. The lung volumes show FEV1 is reduced and FVC is low. A bronchiolo alveolar lavage shows the following, what is the likely diagnsosis?

A 35-year-old road traffic accident patient has developed severe anaphylaxis after an uncrossmatched emergency blood transfusion. The intensivist successfully treats the reaction and now he requires another blood unit to be transfused because of his severely depleted haemoglobin. Which of the following methods will reduce the chance of similar reaction in subsequent transfusion

options.label: D
options.text: Using CPD blood instead of ACD blood.

questions.text: A 64-year-old male presents with fever and weight loss. Clinical examination is unremarkable except for splenomegaly. A FDG-PET scan was performed in this patient thre were multiple retroperitoneal and mediastinal nodes having an increased uptake. Biopsy from one of them showed a high grade non Hodgkin lymphoma. Which of the following is the reason for increased uptake by the lymphnodes.

options.label: A
options.text: Increased glucose receptors in tumour cells

options.label: B
options.text: Rapid anaerobic glycolysis in tumour cells

questions.correct_answer: A. Increased glucose receptors in tumour cells

questions.text: Which amongst the following is not true?

options.label: A
options.text: Blood is the specimen of choice for detection of poisons

options.label: B
options.text: Urine is suitable for single direct spot test

options.label: C
options.text: The concentration of poisons found in urine is important in evaluating the quantity ingested or the toxicity.

options.label: D
options.text: Levels of drugs in the muscle more accurately reflect blood levels than the liver or kidney.

questions.correct_answer: C. The concentration of poisons found in urine is important in evaluating the quantity ingested or the toxicity.

questions.text: A patient is brought to casualty in a state of shock. On examination there is a circular wound (Numbered 1) on front of right side of chest, size 1 cm X 1cm, 3 cm from midline with reddish abraded margins. Hairs around the wound are burnt and brownish in appearance. On further examination another circular wound (Numbered 2) of size 1.5 cm X 1.5 cm with everted margins, is found on the back of right side of chest. Which of the following statements is correct about the underlying wound?

options.label: A
options.text: Wounds numbered 1 and 2 are stab wounds by iron rod

options.label: B
options.text: Wounds numbered 1 and 2 are entry and exit wounds by rifled weapon respectively

options.label: C
options.text: Wound numbered 1 is stab wound by iron rod and wound numbered 2 is entry wound of rifled weapon

options.label: D
options.text: Wounds numbered 1 and 2 are entry and exit wounds by smooth bored weapon respectively

questions.correct_answer: B. Wounds numbered 1 and 2 are entry and exit wounds by rifled weapon respectively

questions.text: Which amongst the following are the features of female skull?

A 40-year-old man presents with lesions on his neck that he finds cosmetically unattractive. On examination of the neck, multiple lesions that seem to be hanging off the skin are shown in the image. Each lesion is small, soft, and pedunculated. The largest lesion is about 4 mm in diameter. Most likely diagnosis is?
A 40 year old farmer presents with lesions on his forearm(shown in image). Colony of the organism on special stain is also shown below.What is the diagnosis ?
A 6 year old boy presents with asymptomatic lesions on dorsal aspect of hands and genitals as shown in image.What is the diagnosis?

A patient suffered from Covid-19 infection with severe symptoms. He recovered and is now presenting with complaints of severe hair loss. The time that is expected to elapse between fever and hair loss is about?

A patient presents with diffuse infiltration of ear lobes, face bilaterally. He also had multiple erythematous infiltrated plaques distributed symmetrically on trunk and extremities. He soon develops painful nodules on extremities with fever and chills. Diagnosis is-

A 55-year-old man presents with fever, chills, fatigue, cough, sore throat, and breathlessness for the past 7 days. He describes the cough as productive and says he is fatigued all the time. He says he is a farmer with daily contact with rabbits, horses, sheep, pigeons, and chickens and reports cleaning the barn 3 days before his symptoms started. The patient denies any history of tick bites. Past medical history is irrelevant. His temperature is 39.40C, pulse is 110/min, and respirations are 26/min. On physical examination, there are decreased breath sounds on the right side. A large tender node is palpable in the right axilla. A chest radiograph reveals multiple homogenous opacities in the lower lobe of the right lung and a right-sided pleural effusions. Gram staining of a sputum sample is negative for any organism. Serology tests are negative. Which of the following is the most likely causative organism for this patient‘s condition?

A 28-year-old man presents to the ofﬁce with complaints of malaise. anorexia, and vomiting for the past 2 weeks. He also says that his urine is dark. The past medical history is unremarkable. The temperature is 36.80C , the pulse is 72/min, the blood pressure is 118/63 mm Hg and the respiratory rate is 15/min. The physical examination reveals a slightly enlarged, tender liver. No edema or spider angiomas are noted. Laboratory testing showed the following: • HBsAg - Positive • lgM anti-HBc <1:1,000 • Anti-HBs -Negative • HBeAg - Positive • Anti HBe - Positive • HBV DNA 2.65 x 109 IU/L • Alpha-fetoprotein 125 ngm What is the most likely cause of this patient's condition?

options.label: B
options.text: Acute exacerbation of chronic HBV infection

questions.correct_answer: B. Acute exacerbation of chronic HBV infection

questions.text: A 54-years old man presents with fever and a painful jaw mass with a yellowish discharge as shown in the image. He says that the jaw mass onset 6 weeks ago and has been progressively increasing in size. He reports a history of chronic alcoholism and 8 currently takes more than 6 drinks daily. His temperature is 31.9°C. On physical examination, there is a 7 x 7 cm mass at the tip of the jaw bone with signiﬁcant surrounding edema and sclerosis. The mass is severely tender to even light palpation and is draining a yellowish malodorous discharge. Oral cavity shows, signs of very poor dentition. Laboratory analysis of the discharge reveals gram positive anaerobic ﬁlamentous bacteria. Which of the following organisms is the as most likely cause of this patient's condition?

A 34—year-old man presents with acute onset seizures and hallucinations. The patient's wife says that he had been on a camping trip to United states a few months earlier to study bats as apart of his research project, but otherwise has not travelled recently. Past medical history is signiﬁcant for hypertension, managed medically with hydralazine and enalapril. The patient's condition rapidly deteriorates, and he passes away. An autopsy is performed and a histologic stained section of the brain is shown in the image. Which of the following receptors are targeted by the pathogen most likely responsible for this patient's a condition?

A 31-year-old woman presents to her primary care provider to discuss the results from a previous urine analysis. She has no new complaints and feels well. Past medical history is signiﬁcant for systemic lupus erythematosus. She was diagnosed 5 years ago and takes hydroxychloroquine every day and prednisone when her condition ﬂares. Her previous urine analysis shows elevated protein levels (4+) and blood (3+). The urine sediment contained red blood cells (6 RBCs/high-power ﬁeld). The treating physician would like to perform a renal biopsy to rule out lupus nephritis. What type of hypersensitivity is suggestive of lupus nephritis?

options.label: A
options.text: Type IV, mediated by CD4+ T cells.

options.label: B
options.text: Type II, mediated by CD4+ T cells.

options.label: C
options.text: Type I, mediated by IgE antibodies.

options.label: D
options.text: Type III, mediated by IgG antibodies.

questions.correct_answer: D. Type III, mediated by IgG antibodies.

questions.text: A 66-year-old farmer is being evaluated for abnormal lung ﬁndings on a low dose chest CT scan obtained as part of his lung cancer screening. He has a 50-pack /year smoking history and has been hesitant to quit. He has a non-productive cough but brushes it away saying he is not bothered by it. He denies ever coughing up blood, breathlessness, chest pain, fatigue, or weight loss. He has never sought any medical care and states that he has always been in good shape. He consumes alcohol moderately and uses marijuana occasionally. He lives with his wife and has not traveled recently. On physical examination, his temperature is 37.1°C), blood pressure is 148/70 mm Hg, and pulse rate is 95/mm. General physical examination is unremarkable. Coarse breath sounds are present bilaterally. The cardiac exam is normal. Laboratory studies show a normal complete blood count and comprehensive metabolic panel. A follow-up high resolution CT scan is performed that shows small irregular sub centimeter pulmonary nodules, several of which are cavitated in both lungs, predominantly distributed in the upper and middle zones. There is no mediastinal or hilar lymphadenopathy. A transbronchial needle aspiration of the lesion is performed which shows a nodular pattern of abundant, granular, mildly eosinophilic cells with grooved nuclei with indented nuclear membranes and a chronic inﬂammation that consists primarily of eosinophils. immunohistochemical staining reveals numerous cells that stain positive for S100 and CD1a. Which of the cells of the human immune system are responsible for this lesion?

A 30-year-old woman seeks evaluation at a clinic complaining of shaking, chills, fevers, and headaches for the last 3 days. There is no history of toss of consciousness or respiratory distress. The vital signs include: temperature 38.3°C , respiratory rate 19/mm, blood pressure 120/80 mm Hg and pulse 94/min (rapid and thread). On general examination, she is pale and the sclera are jaundiced. The laboratory ﬁndings are as follows: Hct – 30%, Total bilirubin : 2.6 mg/dL , Direct bilirubin :0.3 mg/dL. A peripheral smear is shown below. What is the most severe complication of this condition?

A 44-year-old man presents to a clinic for evaluation of difficulty swallowing for the past few days. He says that he has noticed progressively worsening chest pain when he attempts to swallow solids or liquids. He works from a home ofﬁce, has not had any recent sick contacts, and is not currently sexually active. His medical history includes acquired immunodeﬁciency syndrome. He is under HAART. The temperature is 100.6°F, the pulse is 72/min, respirations are 18/min, and the blood pressure is 136/84 mm Hg. The physical examination is notable for a dry mouth with red mucosa and no distinct plaques or patches, and a supple neck with no masses or cervical lymphadenopathy. An esophagogastroduodenoscopy shows small white patches within the oesophageal lumen. A biopsy of one of the lesions is performed and the microscopic appearance of the ﬁnding is shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 40-year-old farmer seeks evaluation at a clinic with complaints of a chronic cough, fevers, and anorexia of several months duration. On examination, he has generalized lymphadenopathy with hepatosplenomegaly. A chest radiograph reveals local inﬁltrates and patchy opacities involving all lung ﬁelds. Fine needle aspiration of an enlarged lymph node shows the presence of intracellular yeast. A fungal culture shows the presence of thick—walled spherical spores with tubercles and microconidia. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

You are working as a resident in COVID 19 intensive care unit with wearing appropriate PPE. As per the current govt biomedical norms regarding COVID19, the image shown here is discarded in which color coded bin?

A 22-year-old G1P0 at 28 weeks gestation by LMP presents to labor and delivery complaining of decreased fetal movement. She has had no prenatal care. On the fetal monitor there are no contractions. The fetal heart rate is 150 beats per minute and reactive. An ultrasound is performed in the radiology department and shows a 28-week fetus with normal-appearing anatomy and size consistent with dates. The placenta is implanted on the posterior uterine wall and its margin is well away from the cervix. A succenturiate lobe of the placenta is seen implanted low on the anterior wall of the uterus. This patient is most at risk for which of the following?

options.label: B
options.text: Fetal exsanguination after rupture of the membranes

questions.correct_answer: B. Fetal exsanguination after rupture of the membranes

questions.text: A 21-year-old woman presents with left lower quadrant pain. An anterior 7-cm ﬁrm adnexal mass is palpated. She undergoes cystectomy and the following is the tumour seen. What percentage of these tumors are bilateral?

A 32-year-old G2P0101 at 20 weeks gestational age presents to the emergency room complaining of constipation and abdominal pain for the past 48 hours. The patient also admits to nausea and vomiting since the evening before. The emergency room doctor who examines the patient calls you and reports that the patient has low-grade fever of 37.7°C (100°F), with a normal pulse and blood pressure. The patient’s abdomen is distended and mildly tender to palpation in all quadrants with high-pitched bowel sounds. She has no rebound tenderness. The patient’s WBC is 13,000, and her electrolytes are normal. You recommend which of the following as the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: The patient likely has constipation related to her pregnancy and should be dis charged with reassurance and instructions to give herself a enema and follow a high-fiber diet with laxative use as needed.

options.label: B
options.text: The patient likely has appendicitis and should be prepped for the operating room immediately to have an emergent appendectomy.

options.label: C
options.text: The patient should be sent to radiology for an upright abdominal x-ray.

options.label: D
options.text: The patient likely has hyperemesis gravidarum and intravenous antiemetics should be administered to the patient.

questions.correct_answer: C. The patient should be sent to radiology for an upright abdominal x-ray.

questions.text: A 42-year-old G4P3104 presents for her well-woman examination. She states her cycles are regular and denies any sexually transmitted diseases. Currently she and her husband use condoms, but they hate the hassle of a coital-dependent method. She is interested in a more effective contraception because they do not want any more children. She reports occasional migraine headache and smokes occasionally. She weighs 78 kg, and her blood pressure is 142/89 mm Hg. During her office visit, you counsel the patient at length regarding birth control methods. Which of the following is the most appropriate contraceptive method for this patient?
A 50-year-old woman is diagnosed with cervical cancer. Which lymph node group would be the first involved in metastatic spread of this disease beyond the cervix and uterus?

In combination birth control pills, which of the following is the primary contraceptive effect of the estrogenic component?
Match the columns with their correct usg parameter
questions.correct_answer: B. A5 B4 C1 D2 E3

questions.text: A 22-year-old woman presents for her first Pap smear. She has been sexually active with only one boyfriend since age 19. Her physical examination is completely normal. However, 2 weeks later her Pap smear results return showing HGSIL. There were no endocervical cells seen on the smear. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Perform a cone biopsy of the cervix

options.label: B
options.text: Repeat the Pap smear to obtain endocervical cells

options.label: C
options.text: Perform colposcopy and directed cervical biopsies

options.label: D
options.text: Order HPV typing on the initial Pap smear

questions.correct_answer: C. Perform colposcopy and directed cervical biopsies

questions.text: A 29-year-old G0 comes to your office complaining of a vaginal dis charge for the past 2 weeks. The patient describes the discharge as thin in consistency and of a grayish white colour. She denies any vaginal or vulvar pruritus or burning. She admits to being sexually active in the past, but has not had intercourse during the past year On physical examination, the vulva appears normal. There is a dis charge present at the introitus.. The vaginal pH is 5.5. The cervix is not inflamed and there is no cervical discharge. Wet smear of the discharge is shown below . Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 38-year-old G1P1 comes to see you for her first prenatal visit at 12 weeks gestational age. She had a previous term vaginal delivery without any complications. You detect fetal heart tones at this visit, and her uterine size is consistent with dates. Two weeks later, the results of the patient’s prenatal labs come back. Her blood type is A–, with an anti-D antibody titer of 1:16. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Schedule an amniocentesis for amniotic fluid bilirubin at 16 weeks.

options.label: D
options.text: Schedule Percutaneous Umbilical Blood Sampling (PUBS) to determine fetal hematocrit at 20 weeks.

While evaluating a 30-year-old woman for infertility, you diagnose the following . You explain that additional testing is necessary because of the woman’s increased risk of congenital anomalies in which organ system?

Examination shows a contracted uterus with hypertonus. A large gush of blood occurs during cervical examination which shows a long closed cervix. The FHR shows severe late deceleartions. A 34-year-old woman p2l2 comes to the physician because of vaginal bleeding, Her last menstrual period was 8 weeks ago, and a home pregnancy test 2 weeks ago was positive. She has had mild uterine cramping but is otherwise asymptomatic. Pelvic examination reveals a 12-14 week, nontender uterus. The remainder of the physical examination is unremarkable. Urine hCG is positive, Pelvic ultrasound reveals the following. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

A 22-year-old woman consults you for treatment of hirsutism. She is obese and has facial acne and hirsutism and periareolar regions and a male escutcheon. Serum LH level is 35 mIU/mL and FSH is 9 mIU/mL. Androstenedione and testosterone levels are mildly elevated, but serum DHEAS is normal. The following is the ultrasound image obtained. Which of the following single agents is the most appropriate treatment of her condition?
You suspect that your infertility patient has an inadequate luteal phase. She should undergo an endometrial biopsy on which day of her menstrual cycle?
All the following structures can be held with the instrument shown except ?

A 25-year-old G3P2 at 39 weeks is admitted in labor at 6cm dilated. The fetal heart rate tracing is reactive. Two hours later, she is reexamined and her cervix is unchanged at 6 cm dilated. An IUPC is placed and the patient is noted to have 280 Montevideo units (MUV) by the IUPC. After an additional 2 hours of labor, the patient is noted to still be 6cm dilated. The fetal heart rate tracing remains reactive. Which of the following is the best next step in the management of this labor?

options.label: A
options.text: Continue to wait and observe the patient.

questions.text: You are delivering a 33-year-old G3P2 and encounter a shoulder dystocia. After performing the appropriate maneuvers, the baby finally delivers, and the paediatricians attending the delivery note the following . Which of the following is the baby’s most likely diagnosis?
The following fetal position is seen in which type of maternal pelvis

A 50 year old woman presents with intermenstrual bleeding for last 6 months, bleeding is not very heavy. A transvaginal ultrasound is done which shows the following image . What is then likely diagnosis of this patient?

A 76-year-old woman presents for evaluation of urinary incontinence. She had a hysterectomy for fibroid tumors of the uterus at age 48. After complete evaluation, you determine that the patoent has genuine stress urinary incontinence. On physical examination, she has a hypermobile urethra, but there is no cystocele or rectocele. Which of the following surgical procedures should you recommend to this patient?

You performed a forceps-assisted vaginal delivery on a 20-year-old G1 at 40 weeks for maternal exhaustion.. A second-degree episiotomy was cut to facilitate delivery. Eight hours after delivery, you are called to see the patient because she is unable to void and complains of severe pain. On examination the following is seen. What is the best management for this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Apply an ice pack to the perineum.

options.label: C
options.text: Place a vaginal pack for 24 hours

questions.text: Which of the following is not a cause of ambiguous genitalia in female child

A young woman complains of headache. On examination, the vision is 6/6 with normal pupillary reactions. She has bitemporal field defects on confrontation visual field examination. Endocrinological evaluation was also done when she was sent to an endocrinologist.

A 6-year-old female fails a school vision screen. Her vision is 6/60 OD and 6/6 OS. According to school policies, her parents were asked to see an ophthalmologist. Her anterior and posterior segment examinations are within normal limits. On alternate cover test, there was esophoria. Refraction with 1% atropine was +5.00 sphere OD and +2.50 sphere OS. What is the most appropriate next step?

options.label: B
options.text: Initiate amblyopia management with patching or pharmacologic agents

options.label: D
options.text: Neuroimaging to further evaluate decreased vision

questions.text: A 48 year old woman came with complain of a staring and bulging eyed appearance. She also gives history of double vision, and often discomfort in moving her eyes. Past medical history is of epilepsy, substance abuse and tuberculosis. Current medication: sodium valproate, vigabatrin, lamotrigine, Rifater (isoniazid, rifampicin, pyrazinamide), ethambutol. The doctor advised thyroid function tests which came out to be normal. He noted upper eyelid retraction, conjunctival congestion, limitation of eye movements. The IOP was 23 mm Hg and cornea was having features of ocular surface disease. There was relative afferent pupillary defect on swinging flash light examination. Diagnosis of Dysthyroid ophthalmopathy was made and the doctor advised systemic steroids. The patient was did not respond well to steroids and orbital decompression was planned. Also, the doctor planned surgery for lid retraction and squint. What would be the correct order of the procedures?

options.label: A
options.text: Orbital decompression, Squint surgery, Eyelid surgery

options.label: B
options.text: Squint surgery, Orbital decompression, Eyelid surgery

options.label: C
options.text: Eyelid surgery, Orbital decompression, Squint surgery

questions.correct_answer: A. Orbital decompression, Squint surgery, Eyelid surgery

questions.text: A 16-year-old adolescent boy presented with a blind, painful eye. Ophthalmologic examination showed band keratopathy, and the anterior chamber and pupil were covered by a pigmented membrane. Ultrasonographic examination showed a microphthalmic eye with an irregular structure behind the lens extending to the optic disc. The eye was enucleated. A vitreous stalk extended from the optic nerve to the lens and tractional membranes extended to the ciliary body processes. What is the etiology of this condition?

A patient presents with abnormal facies, frontal baldness and with weakness of the hands and difficulty in walking. He has difficulty in releasing grip, muscle wasting and weakness. He was sent to ophthalmology department for eye examination. Which of the following might not be seen?

A young patient complains of change of his glasses frequently. One day, he experienced sudden blurry vision and redness in his right eye. The visual acuity noted was 6/36 in that eye while it was 6/6 in the left eye. On examination, there was corneal edema with normal intraocular pressure. Previous reports suggested that his pachymetry was less. What could be the diagnosis here?

A 30 year old patient presented with a 2 week history of gradually worsening vision in his left eye. The patient had been seen once by a neurologist 2 yrs back for flashes. At that time a head CT was normal. The patient was lost to follow up with the neurologist, but the flashes had continued for the 2yr period. The patient did not experience visual changes with activity or movement. The patient reported continued decreasing vision. Goldmann visual fields were done and showed a central scotoma. A MRI was done at this time and showed inflammation of the left optic nerve. A likely diagnosis is?

A 44 year old was feeling that he is not able to see properly with his glasses. He visited an ophthalmologist who did a dilated eye examination. The following were his observations Cornea- clear Anterior chamber- quite and normal depth Iris- Normal pattern On lens, he noted some strange white deposit on the anterior capsule (as shown in pic) Posterior segment- Vitreous was clear Optic disc had few drusens All but one of the following are true for the condition in the figure except

options.label: A

options.label: B

options.label: D

questions.text: 42 year-old male policeman presents to clinic reporting a sore and red eye shortly after a being elbowed during a drug dealer sting operation. He was not wearing protective eyewear. He reports blurry vision. He reports tenderness over his left eye, eyebrow, and cheekbone. Anterior Chamber was deep and quiet and hyphema obscuring 1/3 of the anterior chamber was present. The IOP was 30 mm Hg. He was given topical steroids, antiglaucoma medications and was advised propped up position. What could not be the cause of raised IOP here?

options.label: C
options.text: Blockage of trabecular meshwork by hyphema

questions.text: During an exit exam in Ophthalmology, the examiner was very impressed with the student. He answered many questions with logical interpretation. The examiner wanted to test his ability to identify a less commonly used device in clinical practice, so he showed him the following device in the pic and asked the student to tell few points regarding it. The student stated some facts which he know regarding the device. Which of the following statements was incorrectly stated by the student?

options.label: A
options.text: The device is based on pursuits and saccades

options.label: B
options.text: It can be used to measure visual acuity in a child

options.label: C
options.text: It can be used for detecting blind spot in a patient

options.label: D
options.text: It can be used to detect malingering

questions.correct_answer: C. It can be used for detecting blind spot in a patient

questions.text: While walking through a park late in evening, you suddenly notice a child lying still on the ground by the side of a swing. After finding the child to be unresponsive you yelled for help but didn’t find anyone around you to help you. you then checked for pulse and breathing and found it to be absent. what would be your next course of action?

options.label: A
options.text: Leave the child and search for an AED

options.label: B
options.text: Deliver rescue breaths as most cardiac arrest occur due to breathing problems

options.label: C
options.text: Begin back blows and chest thrusts

options.label: D
options.text: Deliver 30 chest compressions followed by 2 breaths.

questions.correct_answer: D. Deliver 30 chest compressions followed by 2 breaths.

questions.text: A 75-year-old patient is to undergo an emergency laparotomy for subacute bowel obstruction. He suffers from chronic atrial fibrillation and is on warfarin. The patient’s INR is 2.0 on admission. What would be the best course of his management?

options.text: Wait for the INR to correct on its own.

options.label: B
options.text: Carry on with the surgery with FFP transfused post-operatively.

options.label: C

options.label: D
options.text: Proceed with the surgery without correcting INR.

questions.correct_answer: C. Correct INR pre-operatively with FFP and vitamin K

questions.text: A 38 year old patient was diagnosed with COVID pneumonia and is admitted for management of the same. On day 3 of admission his oxygen saturation on room air was found to be 90 % with no tachypnea or respiratory distress. Decision was taken to start him on oxygen therapy. Which of the following oxygen delivery devices will be used initially and at what flow rates should oxygen be started?

A 41-year-old man complains of regurgitation of saliva and of undigested food. An oesophagram was done which is shown below. Manometry shows a hypertensive lower esophageal sphincter with a median IRP 25 mmHg. Which of the following is the safest and most effective treatment of this condition?

options.label: A
options.text: Medical treatment with sublingual nitroglycerin, nitrates, or calcium-channel blockers

options.label: C
options.text: Injections of botulinum toxin directly into the lower esophageal sphincter

questions.text: A previously healthy 79-year-old woman presents with early satiety and abdominal fullness. CT scan of the abdomen, pictured here, reveals a cystic lesion in the body and tail of the pancreas. CT-guided aspiration demonstrates an elevated carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA) level. options.label: C
options.text: Percutaneous drainage of the fluid-filled lesion

options.label: D
options.text: Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP) with pancreatic stent placement

questions.text: A 45-year-old man with a history of chronic peptic ulcer disease undergoes a truncal vagotomy and antrectomy with a Billroth II reconstruction (gastrojejunostomy) for gastric outlet obstruction. Six weeks after surgery, he returns, complaining of postprandial weakness, sweating, lightheadedness, crampy abdominal pain, and diarrhoea. Which of the following would be the best initial management strategy?

options.label: A
options.text: Treatment with a long-acting somatostatin analog

options.label: B
options.text: Dietary advice and counseling that symptoms will probably abate within 3 months of surgery

options.label: C
options.text: Dietary advice and counseling that symptoms will probably not abate but are not dangerous

questions.correct_answer: B. Dietary advice and counseling that symptoms will probably abate within 3 months of surgery

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman complains of postprandial right upper quadrant pain and fatty food intolerance. Ultrasound examination reveals no evidence of gallstones or sludge. options.text: Avoidance of fatty foods and reexamination in 6 months

options.label: D

questions.correct_answer: D. CCK-HIDA scan should be performed to evaluate for biliary dyskinesia

questions.text: A 45-year-old executive experiences increasingly painful retrosternal heartburn, especially at night. He has been chewing antacid tablets. ECG and chest x-ray are normal. An oesophagram shows a hiatal hernia. In determining the proper treatment for a sliding hiatal hernia, which of the following is the most useful modality?

options.label: A
options.text: Barium swallow with cinefluoroscopy during Valsalva maneuver

options.label: D
options.text: Measurement of the size of the hernia on upper GI

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman with no significant past medical history and whose only medication is oral contraceptive pills (OCP) presents to the emergency room with right upper quadrant pain. options.label: B
options.text: Intra-arterial embolization of the hepatic adenoma

questions.text: A 53-year-old woman presents to the emergency room complaining of severe epigastric pain radiating to her back, nausea, and vomiting. options.text: Wide local resection with bilateral inguinal node dissection

questions.text: A 75-year-old woman undergoes an uncomplicated lower extremity arterial bypass. Ten days after surgery the patient presents with sudden onset of abdominal pain and distention. options.label: A

options.label: C

options.text: In an event when splenectomy is performed for uncontrollable splenic hemorrhage, pneumococcus, Haemophilus influenza type B (Hib), and meningococcus vaccinations should be given intraoperatively or immediately postoperatively.

options.text: Postoperative drainage high in triglycerides and amylase is indicative of pancreas injury. Management consists of bowel rest with parenteral nutrition

questions.correct_answer: A. In an event when splenectomy is performed for uncontrollable splenic hemorrhage, pneumococcus, Haemophilus influenza type B (Hib), and meningococcus vaccinations should be given intraoperatively or immediately postoperatively.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male with Crohn’s disease presents with a high output enterocutaneous fistula. He is started on total parenteral nutrition (TPN) to decrease the fistula output and improve his general nutritional status. Which of the following statements are false regarding TPN?

options.label: A
options.text: It may cause fatty liver when used over a long period

options.label: B
options.text: It increases the risk of acalculous cholecystitis

options.label: C
options.text: It may result in metabolic complications such a refeeding syndrome, resulting in hyperkalaemia, hypermagnesaemia, and hyperphosphataemia

options.label: D

In the course of performing a monopolar TURP under spinal block, the nurse anesthetist reports the patient is suddenly markedly confused, brachycardic, and hypertensive. An emergent serum sodium level is 110 mEq/L. The following are the next best steps:

options.label: A
options.text: Switch to bipolar TURP equipment and finish the case.

options.label: B
options.text: Drop the height of the irrigating fluid to <60 cm above the patient, control bleeding, terminate the case, administer furosemide, and begin a calculated dose of hypertonic saline.

options.label: C
options.text: Convert to an open simple prostatectomy

options.label: D
options.text: Measure serum levels of illicit drugs and ammonia.

questions.correct_answer: B. Drop the height of the irrigating fluid to <60 cm above the patient, control bleeding, terminate the case, administer furosemide, and begin a calculated dose of hypertonic saline.

questions.text: A 53-year-old man underwent small bowel resection for GIST of the small bowel. All gross disease was removed at the completion of the operation. options.label: A
options.text: Systemic chemotherapy with Adriamycin and cyclophosphamide

questions.correct_answer: B. Imatinib 400 mg daily for 1 year

questions.text: This flap used for reconstruction of nose is also known as

An18-year-old college freshman is referred for endoscopy with a 12 month history of intermittent retrosternal pain, and one episode of food impaction that spontaneously resolved. options.label: D
options.text: Proton pump inhibitor twice a day .

questions.correct_answer: D. Proton pump inhibitor twice a day .

questions.text: A 25-year-old man presents with a renal mass identified on axial imaging obtained during the evaluation of a pneumothorax. On examination he has multiple raised lesions around his nasal folds. What chromosome is likely altered in this patient given the likely disease?

options.label: A
options.text: Remove the trocar, and open the abdomen immediately.

options.label: B
options.text: Remove the trocar immediately, and proceed with reinsufflation of the abdomen and placement of the trocar at an alternate site.

options.text: Leave the trocar in place, consult a vascular surgeon, and convert to open laparotomy.

options.label: D

questions.correct_answer: C. Leave the trocar in place, consult a vascular surgeon, and convert to open laparotomy.

questions.text: When obtaining pneumoperitoneum with the VERESS needle:

options.label: A

options.text: The most commonly injured vessel is the right iliac vein.

questions.text: The manoeuvre shown below is used to correct bowel diameter disparity between the two ends being anastomosed. This is known as?

You are seeing a 4-month-old infant with poor growth and an enlarged abdomen for follow-up care after an emergency department visit. The parents state that they have taken the infant to the emergency department on several occasions for low blood sugar after the baby began to sleep through the night. One of these episodes was associated with a seizure. The infant has doll-like facies with fat cheeks, protuberant abdomen. Hepatomegaly, renomegaly, short stature, and thin arms and legs. No splenomegaly is noted. You order laboratory tests that reveal elevated lactate, uric acid, and lipid levels, along with a low serum glucose level. Liver transaminases, complete blood cell count, and hemoglobin AlC are within the normal range. You order an echocardiogram that rules out a congenital heart defect with associated congestive heart failure. The family history is unremarkable, and the infant's developmental milestones are appropriate. Of the following, the MOST likely disorder to present with these clinical and laboratory findings is.
questions.correct_answer: B. Glycogen storage disease type I

questions.text: A previously healthy 7-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department for evaluation of decreased urine output. The patient has had diarrhea and vomiting for the past 5 days. Over the last few hours, the patient has become increasingly sleepy. He has a temperature of 38.40C, heart rate of 150 beats/min. respiratory rate of 24 breaths / min and blood pressure of 80/40 mm Hg. His weight is 22 kg. and his height is 120 cm. He has mild facial puffiness, pallor, and prolonged capillary refill time (> 3 seconds). A peripheral intravenous catheter is placed, and a blood sample is sent for evaluation. questions.correct_answer: E. 0.9% normal saline. 440 mL over 30 min

questions.text: A 10 year-old girl is brought to your office for a routine health supervision visit. Her mother reports that the girl has a history of recurrent kidney infections and small kidneys. Her physical examination findings are normal. Her urinalysis results are shown:

An 18-month-old girl is brought to the emergency department because of a 2-day history of fever and vomiting. She has a fever (40.1°C) and is mildly dehydrated. Results of a spot urine test strip analysis are shown:

options.label: A
options.text: All urinary tract infections must be treated with parenteral antibiotics

questions.text: A resident rotating in your office is about to see a 9-year-old girl for a health supervision visit. questions.text: An 11-year-old boy with a rash is brought to the emergency department. He has a temperature of 37.4°C, heart rate of 130 beats/min, respiratory rate of 24 breaths / min, and blood pressure of 110/65 mm Hg. He is pale and ill, but nontoxic in appearance. The boy's temperature is 39.5°C, heart rate is 180 beats/min, respiratory rate is 50 breaths/min, blood pressure is 70/20 mm Hg, and oxygen saturation is 100% on room air. His physical examination reveals a well-nourished but toxic-appearing, lethargic child. He has a nonblanching, purpuric rash evenly distributed over his face, trunk, and upper and lower extremities. His mucous membranes are dry. He is in moderate respiratory distress, with clear lung fields and good bilateral air exchange. Consider the following statements: Symposium is a method of health education characterised by 1. A series of speeches on a selected topic 2. questions.text: A 75-year-old man presents complaining of headache and memory difficulties. He has lost 10 lb since his last office visit 6 months ago. He smoked cigarettes for 40 years but was successful I quitting 10 years ago. He has a history of deep vein thrombosis in his left leg, which was successfully treated by medication. His blood pressure is 135/85 mm Hg, and his temperature is 101° F (38.3° C). He complains of feeling flushed and of sweating. His laboratory values are as follows: Hct, 60%; WBC, 15,000/mm3; platelets, 400,000/mm3; serum erythropoietin, 0.5 U/L. What is the most appropriate treatment for this patient?
questions.explanation:
References:

  • ↳ Sol:
  • ↳ • The elevated hematocrit level, reduced serum erythropoietin level, headache, fever, memory difficulties, and weight loss seen in this patient are characteristic of polycythemia vera.
  • ↳ • Although there is not an overall consensus on treatment of polycythemia vera, phlebotomy is frequently used as an initial treatment.
  • ↳ • Because this patient is older than 70 years and has previously had a thrombotic event, a myelosuppressive agent such as hydroxyurea should be used in addition to phlebotomy.
  • ↳ • This combination of hydroxyurea and phlebotomy has been demonstrated to be an effective therapeutic regimen in controlling the hematocrit in most patients with polycythemia vera and in lowering the risk of thrombosis that occurs with use of phlebotomy alone.
  • ↳ • When hydroxyurea is used, complete blood counts should be frequently monitored to avoid excessive myelosuppression.
  • ↳ • Patients may experience painful leg ulcers. Two reports have shown an increased risk of acute myeloid leukemia in patients taking hydroxyurea, although it remains controversial whether the use of hydroxyurea increases the risk of acute myeloid leukemia.
